citeinfo.title: Active Layer Soil Carbon and Nutrient Mineralization, Barrow, Alaska, 2012

descript.purpose: Atmospheric warming, which is expected to occur more rapidly in the Arctic compared with lower-latitudes, may lead to permafrost degradation, potentially increasing feedbacks of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, and increased nutrient availability for plants. While C stored in permafrost has been the focus of much research, we were interested in feedbacks from warming of the active layer that thaws each year. Microbial processing of organic matter in the active layer is controlled by the balance among soil organic matter content, moisture, and temperature, which are influenced by landscape position and plant community composition. We collected active layer soil across a gradient of microtopographic positions in polygonal tundra in Barrow, Alaska. We hypothesized that C, N, and P mineralization would be greatest in the warmest soils with the greatest soil organic matter content.

theme.themekt: Soil characteristics and soil carbon and nutrient mineralization

dataqual.logic: Three of us checked the data in the electronic file against the raw data sheets.
